statement.text: The gravitational coupling constant α_G = Gm²/(ℏc) is a dimensionless measure of the strength of gravity relative to quantum effects for a particle of mass m. For electrons, α_G ≈ 1.75 × 10⁻⁴⁵, making gravity ~10⁴⁰ times weaker than electromagnetism at the atomic scale. This tiny value is central to the hierarchy problem: why is gravity so extraordinarily weak?

explanation.intuition: The gravitational coupling constant measures how strongly a particle feels gravity compared to quantum effects. For an electron, α_G ≈ 10⁻⁴⁵ means gravity is inconceivably weak at atomic scales. Compare to the fine structure constant α ≈ 1/137 for electromagnetism: the ratio α/α_G ~ 10⁴³ tells us electromagnetism is 10⁴³ times stronger than gravity for electrons! This is why gravity is irrelevant for atomic and molecular physics.
explanation.key_insight: The gravitational coupling constant reveals the hierarchy problem: α_G is tiny because m_e << m_P. Why are fundamental particle masses (meV to hundreds of GeV) so much smaller than the Planck mass (10¹⁹ GeV)? This 10¹⁵-10²² ratio between electroweak scale and Planck scale is unexplained and one of the deepest mysteries in physics. Proposed solutions include supersymmetry, extra dimensions, and anthropic selection.
explanation.technical_details: α_G = Gm²/(ℏc) has the same structure as α = e²/(4πε₀ℏc): both are dimensionless ratios of (interaction strength) to quantum effects. For electrons: α_G = Gm_e²/(ℏc) = (m_e/m_P)² ≈ 1.75 × 10⁻⁴⁵. For protons: α_G(p) = Gm_p²/(ℏc) ≈ 5.9 × 10⁻³⁹. The gravitational force between two electrons is F_G/F_EM = α_G/α ≈ 10⁻⁴³. This ratio is independent of distance since both forces scale as 1/r². The weakness of gravity is why it takes ~10⁵⁷ atoms to make a 1-kg mass that has gravitational effects comparable to EM effects of a single electron.
common_misconceptions: Gravity is 'fundamentally' weaker than EM - MISLEADING: G is just measured in different units; α_G depends on particle mass
α_G is universal - FALSE: it depends on which particle masses you use
The hierarchy problem is solved - FALSE: no consensus solution exists
Gravity becomes strong for heavy particles - TRUE but misleading: 'strong' gravity requires m ~ m_P

definitions_glossary.hierarchy_problem: Why is m_e/m_P ~ 10⁻²² so tiny? Why is gravity so weak?
definitions_glossary.planck_mass: m_P = √(ℏc/G) ≈ 22 μg, mass scale where gravity and quantum effects balance

planck_mass.note: Gravity and quantum effects balance at m = m_P

force_ratios.interpretation: Electromagnetism is 10⁴² times stronger than gravity for electrons
Strong force is 10³⁸ times stronger than gravity for protons
Even the 'weak' force is 10³³ times stronger than gravity

hierarchy_numbers.question: Why is this ratio so large? No known fundamental reason.

Hierarchy problem connects to Planck scale significance

learning_objectives: Calculate gravitational coupling constant for given particle mass
Compare gravity strength to other forces using dimensionless ratios
Appreciate the magnitude of the hierarchy problem
Understand why gravity is negligible at atomic scales
common_errors: Thinking α_G is the same for all particles (it depends on mass)
Missing that α_G = 1 at Planck mass
Confusing α_G with G (one is dimensionless, one is not)
